newsitem.title: UK: Lowe ad network expands into Argentina, Venezuela.
newsitem.headline: Lowe ad network expands into Argentina, Venezuela.

text.p: Lowe & Partners Worldwide, The Lowe Group's main advertising network, said on Tuesday it had significantly expanded in Latin America by establishing its first presence in Argentina and Venezuela.

Frank Lowe, the chairman and founder of The Lowe Group, which is owned by Interpublic Group of Companies Inc in the United States, said the agency had taken a "substantial" minority stake in two creative-led ad agencies.

He said the new link-ups with Agulla & Baccetti in Buenos Aires and Concept Publicidad in Caracas were important for Lowe, which, like other Western-based agency networks, faced slow growth in the advertising industries in Europe and the United States.
"Europe is not growing very dramatically. The U.S. is not," he told a news conference.
Lowe & Partners has described Latin America and Asia as priority growth areas for its network.

Jose Eduardo Cazarin, the president of Lowe & Partners Latin America, based in Brazil, told journalists the new partnerships meant Lowe now had a presence in Latin America's five most important advertising markets.
Lowe already had a minority stake in agencies in Mexico, Brazil and Colombia.
Cazarin told Reuters that Lowe expected to announce a new partnership soon with an ad agency in Chile.
He also said Lowe & Partners would be looking next year at possible link-ups with local agencies in Uruguay, Peru, Puerto Rico and somewhere in Central America.
Lowe is ranked 13th among worldwide agency networks, with $3.6 billion in billings.
Frank Lowe said it was crucial for advertising agency networks to be present in the same emerging markets as their multinationals clients.
But he said the method used by U.S.-based networks that traditionally set up their own branch offices in emerging markets no longer really worked.
Lowe said it made more sense now for Western-based networks like Lowe to link up with local partners, who knew the local market and culture, and knew what kind of advertising would work.
He declined to give details on how much money Lowe was investing in the agencies in Venezuela and Argentina.
Juan Quilici, the general manager of Concept Publicidad, said the link with Lowe would empower his agency and its mostly Venezuelan-based clients.
"You have to open windows to the world. I think the Lowe group can do that for us," he told the joint news conference.
Quilici said the Lowe partnership with Concept Publicidad, which had been the leading independent advertising agency in Venezuela, now placed it eighth or ninth among agency networks in Caracas.
Ramiro Agulla, who founded Agulla & Bacetti in Argentina with Carlos Bacetti in 1989, said the advertising industry in Latin America was growing rapidly.
"It's a very young market. We might draw things from other markets" including the United States. "The advertising industry in Latin America is only just now finding its own identity," he said.
Agulla said Ammirati Puris Lintas, another agency network owned by Interpublic, had been interested in a partnership with Agulla & Bacetti, but Lowe had provided a better fit.
